Title: Utilization of health facilities and trained birth attendants for childbirth in rural Bangladesh: An empirical study
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Seaton Hall, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States; Department of Mathematics, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Seaton Hall, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States; Rumsey D.J., Department of Mathematics, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Abstract: The majority of births in rural Bangladesh are carried out in unhygienic conditions by relatives and traditional birth attendants (TBAs). This results in a high incidence of maternal and infant mortality that could be reduced if childbirth were to occur in health centers or under the supervision of trained TBAs (TTBAs). In this paper, we examined factors associated with utilization of modern health resources for childbirth in 39 villages of Bangladesh. We followed a retrospective survey research design to collect relevant information from couples who experienced childbirth during a two-year period from July 1, 1995 to June 1997. The data indicate that slightly over 11% of the deliveries were performed by trained personnel with the rest attended by TBAs. Multivariate analysis clearly shows that delivery complications was the most significant factor determining the use of modern health care resources for childbirth, followed by parental education, and pre-natal care. We conclude that quick response to delivery complications and improved access to hospitals and TTBAs can reduce the risk of infant and maternal mortality and morbidity in rural Bangladesh. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

Author full names: De Dunn, Sujata (6507197105); Paul, Bimal Kanti (7202710676)
Title: Labour-market participation of Asian Indian immigrant women in the Greater Kansas City Metropolitan Area, USA
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States
Authors with affiliations: De Dunn S., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States; Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States
Abstract: Immigrants are changing the composition of the American population at the end of the twentieth and into this century, just as they have done for many decades. The amended Immigration and Naturalization Act of 1965 resulted in a steady flow of professional Asian Indians to the United States. While receiving indirect attention in several studies, relatively little is known about the labour-market participation of Asian Indian immigrant women. This research aims to determine the economic and non-economic factors that influence the participation of Asian Indian immigrant women in the labour market of the Greater Kansas City Metropolitan Area. On the basis of 160 responses from a questionnaire survey, this research found that annual income, years in current job, occupation type, and the nature of investment in India were the pertinent economic factors, while non-economic factors range from age, urban residential background, education, number of years in the US, the decision to work, and some perceptions on work, homemaking and household income contribution. Findings from this study are discussed in the context of existing theories on international migration, particularly those dealing with the labourforce participation of immigrants. © 2002 John Wiley and Sons, Ltd.

Title: Female activity space in rural Bangladesh
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., United States
Abstract: Mobility and employment opportunities of women have traditionally been restricted in rural Bangladesh. As poverty increases, women in poor families seek to work to support families. This trend has resulted in expansion of female activity space, after many years of stability. This article analyzes female space in the context of purdah, the patriarchal family structure, and the spatial organization of rural settlements. It discusses ethnic and other differentials that influence female space. Governmental and nongovernmental organizations are urged to create additional employment opportunities for rural women, so as to expand further their activity space. -Author
Index Keywords: Bangladesh; activity space; developing country; employment opportunities; employment opportunity; family structure; female mobility; female space; purdah; rural area; women

Title: Flood problems in Bangladesh: Is there an indigenous solution?
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Lakehead University, Thunder Bay, P7B 5E1, Ontario, Canada; Department of Geography, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Rasid H., Department of Geography, Lakehead University, Thunder Bay, P7B 5E1, Ontario, Canada; Paul B.K., Department of Geography, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: Bangladesh, situated on the delta of the Ganges, the Brahmaputra, and the Meghna rivers, experiences two distinct types of inundations: (a) river floods resulting from excessive runoff contributed by monsoon precipitation and (b) coastal floods induced by storm surges of tropical cyclones. The river floods are normal annual events and human settlements and agricultural practices have adapted admirably well to their regimes. Abnormal floods that occur once in every few years cause serious damage to crops and properties. To minimize flood losses, a number of modern engineering projects have been constructed within Bangladesh. However, the successful solution of the problem would probably require some international collaboration for basinwide unified systems planning, since large parts of the drainage basins of Bangladesh lie beyond its borders. In the absence of such collaboration, internal resources should be utilized for the construction of smaller public projects, such as polders, and for encouraging and reinforcing various types of indigenous adjustments to floods. There are very few successful indigenous adjustments to coastal floods. Most of the structural solutions, such as community shelters and higher embankments, are expensive public projects that are probably beyond the means of the internal resources of the country. © 1987 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.
Author Keywords: Abnormal floods; Coastal floods; Engineering flood control; Floodplains; Indigenous adjustments; International drainage basins; Normal floods

Title: Health service resources as determinants of infant death in rural Bangladesh: An empirical study
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, United States
Abstract: Using empirical data collected from a rural area of Bangladesh, this paper examines the relative importance of availability of health care resources on infant death. Following many health care studies, this paper hypothesizes that the likelihood of infant death is a function of accessibility to different types of health facilities and personnel. Both univariate and multivariate analyses of data indicate that the distance to a qualified physician of Western medicine exerts significant influence on infant deaths. Other variables considered are distance to Upazila Health Complex (UHC), Family Welfare Center (FWC), and non-qualified doctors. © 1991.
Author Keywords: accessibility; Bangladesh; infant mortality; multivariate analysis

Title: Farmers' Responses to the Flood Action Plan (FAP) of Bangladesh: An empirical study
Affiliations: Kansas State University, Manhattan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Kansas State University, Manhattan, United States
Abstract: The World Bank has recently prepared a Flood Action Plan (FAP) to solve the flood problems of Bangladesh. The FAP proposed construction of embankments on both sides of all major rivers. There is, however, strong opposition in the country to the "structural solution" to its flood problems. The objectives of this paper are to study the farmers' level of awareness, responses to, and the possible positive and negative impacts of the proposed embankment projects as outlined in the FAP. The data for this study were derived from field surveys conducted in two rural areas of Bangladesh. The survey data showed that slightly less than half of the total respondents had heard about the proposed construction of the embankment. The data further showed that the respondents overwhelmingly supported the embankment projects of the FAP. They were also aware of both positive and negative impacts of embankment construction. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Bangladesh; developing country; embankment project; farmers' attitudes; farmers' response; Flood Action Plan; flood control; river embankment
Funding Details: United Nations Development Program; United States Agency for International Development
Funding Texts: Soon after the 1988 flood, four reports were commissioned by the French and Japanese governments, the United Nations Development Program (UNDP), and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) (Boyce, 1990, p. 425). These reports have proffered an array of viewpoints; with the exception of USAID’s Eastern Waters Study (Bogem, Lydon and Seckler, 1989), the remaining three reports favor a structural solution to the Rood problem of Bangladesh. The most dramatic and costly proposals were made by a team of French engineers which recommend the construction of a 3,350 km continuous embankment along the major rivers of the country

Title: Gender ratios in the smas of bangladesh: Is the gap declining?
Affiliations: Department of Geography Dickens Hall, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS, 66506, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Department of Geography Dickens Hall, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS, 66506, United States
Abstract: This paper examines the gender ratios of the Statistical Metropolitan Areas (SMAs) of Bangladesh for the last intercensal period (1981-1991) and discusses the factors that are associated with the changing gender ratios of the SMAs. The latest population census of Bangladesh suggests that the gender ratios of its four SMAs decl ined markedly during the last decade. This decline is explained in terms of the decentralization of government administration, initiation of rural development programs, increased opportunities for over-seas employment, and openings of employment for rural women in the garment industries of the SMAs. © 1994 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Coping mechanisms practised by drought victims (1994/5) in North Bengal, Bangladesh
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Dickens Hall, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506-0801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Dickens Hall, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506-0801, United States
Abstract: Droughts are recurrent features in Bangladesh, affecting plant growth and leading to loss of crop production, food shortages and, for many people, starvation. The main objective of this study is to examine the means by which residents of a drought-affected area of Bangladesh cope with this hazard. Data were collected during the summer of 1995 from 301 drought-affected households located in northwestern Bangladesh. Analysis suggests that respondent households practised an array of adjustments to mitigate adverse effects of the 1994/5 drought. While both high- and low-income households were affected by the drought, households belonging to the lower socioeconomic group suffered the most, receiving the least support from the national government. Government responses were delayed and inadequate in providing financial and other assistance to the drought victims. It is suggested that the government should be prepared for drought long before the occurrence of such an event.
Author Keywords: Adjustments; Coping strategies; Drought impact; Drought response; Sources of support
Index Keywords: Bangladesh; coping strategy; drought; humanitarian aid
Funding Details: Natural Hazards Research and Applications Information Center

Special thanks are extended to all field investigators, particularly Md. Hamidur Rahman, Khandoker Zakir Hayat and Md. Mofaqkharul Islam for conducting the field survey in Bangladesh. I would also like to thank Michael J. Kollmeyer and Timothy Perkes for drafting figures used in this paper.

Title: A case for greater interaction between the geographers of developed and developing countries
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS, 66506-0801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS, 66506-0801, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Funding Details: Rockefeller Foundation
Funding Texts: Other areas of interaction are field research in developing Countries by geographers (including geography students) of developed countries, studies in developed countries by the students from developing countries, and exchange of professional geographers. The latter would enable geographers of developing countries to update their lectures with the new developments in the discipline. Geographers and geography students of developed countries should explore the possibilities of obtaining funding to visit, conduct research, or spend sabbaticals in developing countries. The Fulbright Scholar Program and other organizations, e.g., the Rockefeller Foundation, provide financial support for US. geography students to conduct Ph.D. research in developing countries. Geography departments in developing countries can provide a base for foreign students conducting this field research. Similar opportunities exist for the geography faculty of one world to teach or conduct field research in the other world. The Fulbright Teacher Exchange Program and Indo-US. Subcommission on Education and Culture Award are some of the organizations active in exchanging and training scholars of both worlds. The Fulbright Scholars in Residence Program, which supports foreign faculty in US. universities for a semester or an academic year, can contribute to the international perspective in U.S. geography departments. While these scholars are in the United States, they can also receive funding to give guest lectures at American universities (see McKim 1989, 19), further expanding their influence. The United Nation’s Transfer of Knowledge Through Expatriate Nationals (TOK-TEN) program can play an important role in exchanging geographic knowledge between the two worlds. The program provides an opportunity for Third World professionals currently working in the First World to return to their home countries for a limited time and share their knowledge and experience with local counterparts. This program is reported to be successful in many developing countries (Logan 1990,223). A formal collaboration program between geography departments of developed and developing countries should also be encouraged. The British Council initiated one such program between the Department of Geography at the University of Zambia and the Department of Environmental Sciences at the University of Stirling, U.K. (see Akhtar 1988, 102). The main purpose of the program was to strengthen the physical geography and natural resources programs of the University of Zambia. Greater interaction can also be possible by establishing sister departments between uni- versities in Western and Third World countries. Through this program, “staff exchanges might be arranged; students might move in both directions for training and field experience; information and materials might be shared; and each partner would be shaped by a sustained pattern of interaction in some depth” (Wilbanks 1993,2). Conferences and study tours also can bring together professional geographers of different worlds. The AAG Committee on International Research and Exchanges, for example, provided financial support for geographers from less affluent countries to attend the 1992 IGC Congress in Washington, D.C. The AAG should initiate a similar support program for overseas geographers so that some can attend the AAG annual meeting. Financial support is also available for scholars of developing countries from foreign agencies residing in their countries to attend conferences and short training sessions in the developed countries. Geographers of developing countries must explore these opportunities.

Title: Determinants of infant mortality in Bangladesh: implications for establishing health facilities.
Source title: Research in Contemporary & Applied Geography: a Discussion Series - State University of New York at Binghampton
Affiliations: United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., United States
Abstract: Based on a sample of 1743 women surveyed in 1984, it indicates that the probability of survival through infancy varies according to the accessibility of health facilities, with, in order of importance the distance to the doctor, to dispensary, to a Thana health complex, and to a family welfare centre.-P.Creese(CDS)

Title: Family planning availability and contraceptive use in rural Bangladesh: An examination of the distance decay effect
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, K.S 66506, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, K.S 66506, United States
Abstract: Using empirical data collected from a rural area of Bangladesh, this paper examines the effect of family planning availability on contraceptive use. The hypothesis is that the likelihood of contraceptive adoption is a function of accessibility to two different types of family planning service outlets (i.e. distance from these outlets has an impact on the use of contraception by married women of reproductive age, 15-49 yr). But the field data do not show a distance decay effect between availability and use of both clinical and non-clinical contraceptive methods. The observed effect is explained in terms of the presence of paved roads in the study area. The policy implications of this finding are discussed. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Bangladesh; contraceptive availability; contraceptive use; developing country; distance decay effect; empirical studies; family planning; family planning availability; fertility impact; policy implication; population characteristics; rural area; transport and communications

Author full names: Choudhury, Nusha Yamina (7102847651); Paul, Alak (56895551600); Paul, Bimal Kanti (7202710676)
Title: Impact of costal embankment on the flash flood in Bangladesh: A case study
Affiliations: Dept. of Geogr. and Environment, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Department of Geography, University of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh; Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, Seaton Hall, United States
Authors with affiliations: Choudhury N.Y., Dept. of Geogr. and Environment, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Paul A., Department of Geography, University of Chittagong, Chittagong, Bangladesh; Paul B.K., Department of Geography, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS 66506, Seaton Hall, United States
Abstract: Coastal areas of Bangladesh frequently experience tropical cyclones and associated tidal bore. In order to prevent cyclonic or storm-surge flooding and to increase crop production by preventing intrusion of saline ocean water, many coastal embankment projects were initiated in the 1960s by the Bangladesh government. After construction of these embankments, particularly their reconstruction in 1991 has increased the frequency of flash floods in coastal areas. The objective of this study is to examine to what extent the reconstruction of embankment is responsible for the increased severity of flash flooding at the Chokoria thana of the Cox's Bazar district, Bangladesh. Using hydrological data and perception of the respondents on the increased flooding through the rapid rural appraisal (RRA) method, it was found that severity of the flood increased after the reconstruction of embankments in 1991. Other causes of increased flooding is also explored. © 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
